discussion.content: Answer should be 1, 1, both cannot excess because its a new user

comments.content: i disagree. it doesnt expressly say that user1 is a new user, thus he is an existing user. only user2 is a new user.

discussion.content:
I think the given answer is correct:

What other users are saying about: 
"Allow sharing only with guests who are already in your directory. These guests may exist in your directory because they previously accepted sharing invitations or because they were manually added, such as through Azure B2B collaboration. (To see the guests in your organization, go to the Guests page in the Microsoft 365 admin center)."

Is correct, however, if you add the user as a guest user in the tenant and than create the link. The user will already be member of the tenant. If you first create the link, than add the user to your tenant, the user will not be able to access the link. I imagine they compare the link date with the user account creation date.

The second box should be the third one.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/sharepoint/turn-external-sharing-on-or-off#which-option-to-select
In the description of Existing guests, it says
"Allow sharing only with guests who are already in your directory. These guests may exist in your directory because they previously accepted sharing invitations or because they were manually added, such as through Azure B2B collaboration. (To see the guests in your organization, go to the Guests page in the Microsoft 365 admin center)."
Given answer is wrong. I just tested it and a newly made guest user in my tenant with the allowed domain still could not be sent the onedrive doc.

comments.content: to elaborate it says EXISTING USERS ONLY in the onedrive setting. A new user even in the whitelisted tenant won't be allowed.

I also think that given answer is correct. User2 is newly invited to the tenant, so after accepting the invitation, the user is an "existing" external account and thus link can be created for the user. However User2 must be invited upfront by a User Administrator or Global Admin. The OneDrive setting shown in the exhibit prevents the owner of the onedrive to invite users automatically by just creating a share link to a file or folder.

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that contains the users shown in the following table.
//IMG//

You need to prevent users in the finance department from sharing files with users in the research department.
Which type of policy should you configure?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
So, A, C or D would stop you uploading to web1.contoso.com and web2.contoso.com, but only A would stop you uploading to ONLY web1.contoso.com and web2.contoso.com.

C would stop you from uploading to <anysubdomain>.contoso.com and D would stop you uploading to web<anynumber>.contoso.com, both of which could have unintented consequences.

So, like any multiple choice, it seems we need to go with the MOST correct answer, A.

Selected Answer: C
In real life, I would block the whole domain, not just specific URLs. If you can trust two addresses in the same external domain, you shouldn't trust any site in the domain.

comments.content: i disagree. doing entire domain wide blocks could break other apps. keep your denials as focused as possible. same as never use any | any rule.

discussion.content: So what's the real answer here anyone? Its confusing...

Selected Answer: A
an * is a wildcard for example :
 *.contoso.com wil include evrything befor .contoso.com and will be blocked
web*.contoso.com 
web1wil be blocked
web2 wil be blocked
web3 wil be blocked

so the only correct awnser is A
I would say C as *contoso.com according to de site matches ://anysubdomain.contoso.com/

Selected Answer: D
Why it is not D?
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/dlp-configure-endpoint-settings?view=o365-worldwide

comments.content: Because you will also block all other numbers (web3, web4,...). Question is only to block web1 and web2
Because web*.contoso.com would block not only web1.contoso.com and web2.contoso.com, but also, web4, web5, ..... etc.

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that uses Microsoft SharePoint Online.
You need to ensure that users can only share files with users at specified partner companies. The solution must minimize administrative effort.
What should you do?
questions.answer_description:
Limiting domains -
You can limit domains by allowing only the domains you specify or by allowing all domains except those you block.
To limit domains at the organization level
1. Go to Sharing in the SharePoint admin center, and sign in with an account that has admin permissions for your organization.
2. Under Advanced settings for external sharing, select the Limit external sharing by domain check box, and then select Add domains.
3. To create an allowlist (most restrictive), select Allow only specific domains; to block only the domains you specify, select Block specific domains.
4. List the domains (maximum of 3000) in the box provided, using the format domain.com.
5. Etc.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sharepoint/restricted-domains-sharing

discussion.content:
Setting: EnableMIPLabels.
Type: Sensitivity labels apply to groups of services like Outlook, Microsoft Teams, and SharePoint (Microsoft 365).
 
https://learn.microsoft.com/es-es/azure/active-directory/enterprise-users/groups-assign-sensitivity-labels

The type needs to be Microsoft 365. The key here is the wording of "assign Sensitivity1 to Group1" instead of using a label policy for the group. Many of these test questions appear to not be written carefully, so it is easy to miss in this case.
Proposed answer is correct: statement says you need to apply Label1 to Group1. Labels can be applied to M365 groups only

I think on "Type" this is multi answer question.
So Distribution, Mail-enabled security and Microsoft 365 can be assigned a Label Policy.
Basically all groups that are email enabled. Groups need to have an email address. Not possible for Security only group.

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You have a Microsoft 365 E5 tenant that contains a published sensitivity label named Sensitivity1.
You plan to create an Azure Active Directory group named Group1 and assign Sensitivity1 to Group1.
How should you configure Group1? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//
questions.answer_description:
Box 1: EnableMIPLabels -
The sensitivity label option is only displayed for groups when all the following conditions are met:
* The feature is enabled, EnableMIPLabels is set to True in from the Azure AD PowerShell module.
* The group is a Microsoft 365 group.
* Etc.

Box 2: Microsoft 365 -
Incorrect:
* Not ClassificationList:
Classic classifications are the old classifications you set up by defining values for the ClassificationList setting in Azure AD PowerShell. When this feature is enabled, those classifications will not be applied to groups.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/enterprise-users/groups-assign-sensitivity-labels
